Implements on‑site habitat stewardship within multistory agroforestry systems by managing canopy density, retaining pruning residues as mulch, controlling competing vegetation and invasives, and protecting regenerating understory. These actions stabilize soils, moderate microclimate/humidity, and maintain vertical structure that supports foraging, nesting, and refuge for native taxa across trophic levels.

Restores or enhances missing forest structure and ecological processes by establishing/maintaining a layered overstory–understory mosaic with site‑adapted, often native, woody and non‑woody species. This (re)creates functional habitat elements—shade, litter inputs, root stratification, and continuous nectar/fruit resources—improving ecological function on degraded working lands.

Implements on-the-ground stewardship within riparian buffers: mechanical invasive removal, selective pruning, targeted spot herbicide where allowed, biological control, separation/border actions (fencing to exclude livestock), and visitor management (trail routing) to protect ground cover, stabilize banks, reduce pollutant delivery, and maintain shade—core outcomes of NRCS 391.

Where buffer projects rebuild riparian community structure (trees/shrubs understory), restore abiotic conditions (e.g., bank microtopography, infiltration, shading to lower stream temperatures), and enhance biotic processes (nutrient cycling, pollination), the work constitutes ecosystem & natural process (re)creation consistent with CMP 1.2.

NRCS-390 establishes dense native herbaceous buffers in riparian transition zones to improve water quality, dissipate stream energy, trap sediment, and provide wildlife habitat —the core of CMP 1.1 Site/Area Stewardship (mechanical/chemical invasive control, fencing/grazing control, and mowing timed to avoid sensitive periods); this creates low-structure corridors along waterways that increase insect prey and safe movement while reducing disturbance along edges—benefits are indirect and depend on adjacency to species’ core habitat. Applicability note: benefits accrue where the species occurs within or adjacent to riparian corridors; confirm local habitat overlap during planning.

NRCS-390 establishes dense native herbaceous buffers in riparian transition zones to improve water quality, dissipate stream energy, trap sediment, and provide wildlife habitat —the core of CMP 1.1 Site/Area Stewardship (mechanical/chemical invasive control, fencing/grazing control, and mowing timed to avoid sensitive periods); this reduces competition from invasive species, improves soil moisture and microclimate at the stream edge, and stabilizes banks, aiding recruitment and persistence of riparian-associated native plants. Applicability note: benefits accrue where the species occurs within or adjacent to riparian corridors; confirm local habitat overlap during planning.

NRCS-390 establishes dense native herbaceous buffers in riparian transition zones to improve water quality, dissipate stream energy, trap sediment, and provide wildlife habitat —consistent with CMP 1.2 Ecosystem & Natural Process (Re)Creation by rebuilding the structural (herbaceous corridor) and functional (hydrologic roughness, nutrient retention) components of riparian ecosystems; this creates low-structure corridors along waterways that increase insect prey and safe movement while reducing disturbance along edges—benefits are indirect and depend on adjacency to species’ core habitat. Applicability note: benefits accrue where the species occurs within or adjacent to riparian corridors; confirm local habitat overlap during planning.

Road/Trail/Landing Closure & Treatment (NRCS 654) is an on‑site stewardship action: it physically decommissions travelways (barriers, excavation/reshaping, culvert removal, ripping to relieve compaction, reconnecting drainage), controls invasive plants, establishes adapted vegetation, and stabilizes slopes to immediately reduce erosion, sediment, contaminants, dust, and human disturbance while re‑connecting wildlife movement corridors.

NRCS 654 restores missing ecosystem structure and processes by removing road prisms, re‑establishing natural hill‑slope contours, reconnecting channels/floodplains and subsurface drainage, and re‑vegetating disturbed areas—thereby restoring hydrologic, geomorphic, and biotic functions at the site scale.

Shallow Water Development & Management (NRCS 646) is site-level stewardship: impoundment construction/earthwork, water-level control (1–18 in), invasive control, and management actions (burning, disking, dewatering, fish exclusion for amphibian units). / Hydroperiod control (1–18 in), seasonal flooding/drawdown, and mudflat/shallow-pool creation under NRCS 646 provide the site-scale conditions required by this species; actions align with site stewardship by timing depths to breeding/foraging windows and controlling fish access where needed for amphibians. / Implements on-the-ground stewardship needed to achieve and maintain 646 habitat conditions: mechanical management (disking, mowing) to set back succession; targeted chemical control only where allowed; biological control where appropriate; separation/border actions and visitor management to prevent disturbance; and operational water-level management to meet seasonal habitat needs.

NRCS 646 builds/restores shallow-water ecosystem structure and processes via hydrologic regime management, mudflat creation, vegetated shallows, off-channel refugia, and moist-soil plant communities. / Hydroperiod control (1–18 in), seasonal flooding/drawdown, and mudflat/shallow-pool creation under NRCS 646 provide the site-scale conditions required by this species; actions align with ecosystem/process (re)creation by timing depths to breeding/foraging windows and controlling fish access where needed for amphibians. / Creates or restores shallow-water wetland structure and hydrologic processes by impounding or regulating water (diking, ditching, excavating, flooding) to achieve 1–18 in. depth over most of the area during planned inundation, providing habitat for shorebirds, wading birds, waterfowl, fish, reptiles, and amphibians. These actions rebuild ecosystem structure and abiotic/biotic functions—core to CMP 1.2.

Silvopasture involves on‑the‑ground site management: selective thinning, planting, control of competing vegetation, prescribed/rotational grazing, and fencing/gating to exclude livestock from sensitive areas (e.g., wetlands, riparian buffers, caves, karst). These Site/Area Stewardship actions directly reduce stresses (erosion, sedimentation, nutrient runoff, heat stress, trampling) and improve microclimate, infiltration, and understory composition. Apply only where the species’ habitat overlaps with wooded pasture or forest–edge systems; avoid xeric open habitats.

Apply only where the species’ habitat overlaps with wooded pasture or forest–edge systems; avoid xeric open habitats.

Silvopasture establishment can rebuild structural and functional components of degraded woodland or pasture: tree rows/clumps re‑create vertical structure, roots stabilize soils and enhance infiltration, and managed grazing simulates natural herbivory. These actions restore ecosystem processes (shade, litter inputs, carbon sequestration) consistent with Ecosystem & Natural Process (Re)Creation.

Watering Facility (NRCS 614) is on‑site stewardship: providing alternative water away from sensitive areas; locating/spacing troughs to improve animal distribution; stabilizing heavy‑use areas; using ramps for controlled stream/pond access; installing backflow/overflow controls; anchoring on firm foundations; adding fencing/visibility markers; and timing O&M—all to reduce habitat stressors (trampling/erosion, contamination, riparian degradation) and improve site function.

Wetland Wildlife Habitat Management (NRCS 644) is on‑the‑ground site stewardship: using habitat evaluation to identify limiting factors and then manipulating vegetation and hydrology (e.g., seasonal drawdowns, water‑level control), controlling invasive/noxious and nuisance species (mechanical/chemical/biological), installing and maintaining structural measures, stabilizing access/heavy‑use areas, and adjusting operations to protect sensitive periods—all to reduce stressors and improve wetland habitat condition and function.

Windbreak/Shelterbelt Establishment (NRCS 380) is an on-the-ground site stewardship action: site preparation, planting rows of adapted native/noninvasive woody species, controlling invasive/noxious vegetation (mechanical/chemical/biological), orienting plantings perpendicular to prevailing winds, specifying density/height/length, and carrying out O&M (replacement, thinning/pruning, protection from insects/disease/competition). These reduce stressors and improve habitat and microclimate functions.
